title: R46113
content: This report analyzes annual appropriations for the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for FY2020, comparing enacted FY2019 appropriations, the Trump Administration's FY2020 budget request, and the enacted appropriations measures. It also provides additional informational resources on DHS appropriations and a list of CRS policy experts for consultation. The suite of CRS reports on homeland security appropriations tracks legislative action and congressional issues related to DHS appropriations, focusing on discretionary funding amounts. These reports do not analyze specific issues related to mandatory funding or follow other legislation related to DHS programs. The Appendix explains budgetary concepts such as budget authority, obligations, outlays, discretionary and mandatory spending, and offsetting collections. The curr_chunk discusses terms related to appropriations process, including authority, obligations, discretionary and mandatory spending, and adjustments to spending caps under the Budget Control Act. All amounts in CRS reports on homeland security appropriations represent budget authority. Calculations use unrounded data for precision. The curr_chunk provides unrounded data from FY2019 annual appropriations and supplemental appropriations, sourced from specific legislative acts. The curr_chunk provides data from FY2019 annual appropriations and supplemental appropriations, including funding for natural disasters and security/humanitarian needs at the U.S.-Mexico border. Data sources include specific legislative acts for FY2020 requested, House Appropriations Committee-recommended, Senate Appropriations Committee-recommended, and FY2020 enacted levels. The curr_chunk provides data from FY2019 annual appropriations and supplemental appropriations, including funding for natural disasters and security/humanitarian needs at the U.S.-Mexico border. Data for the FY2020 enacted levels are drawn from the explanatory statement accompanying P.L. 116-93, Division D of which is the FY2020 Department of Homeland Security Appropriations Act. Scoring methodology is consistent across this report, relying on data provided by the Appropriations Committees that has been developed with Congressional Budget Office (CBO) methodology. The Trump Administration released its detailed budget request for FY2020 on March 18, 2019, following a lapse in FY2019 annual appropriations. The legislative process for appropriations for the Department of Homeland Security for FY2020 is outlined, from the initial request to the enactment of annual appropriations in Division D of P.L. 116-93. The Trump Administration's budget proposal for FY2020 was delayed past the deadline outlined in the Budget Act of 1974. The request for the Department of Homeland Security was $51.68 billion in adjusted net discretionary budget authority, a 4.6% increase from the previous year. The Trump Administration requested additional funding for FEMA and the Coast Guard in FY2019 through the Department of Homeland Security Appropriations Act, 2019. This included $14.08 billion for FEMA in disaster relief funding and $190 million in Overseas Contingency Operations/Global War on Terror designated funding for the Coast Guard. The House Appropriations Committee marked up H.R. 3931, the Department of Homeland Security Appropriations Act, 2020, which included $52.80 billion in adjusted net discretionary budget authority. This was $1.12 billion above the Administration's request and $3.39 billion above the enacted level of annual appropriations for FY2019. The bill also included $14.08 billion in disaster relief-designated funding. The House Appropriations Committee-reported Defense Appropriations bill included OCO funding to be transferred to the Coast Guard. Amendments adopted in full committee markup resulted in the initial CBO scoring exceeding the subcommittee allocation by over $3 billion, later revised to $1.9 billion. The Senate Appropriations Committee marked up S. 2582, its version of the Department of Homeland Security Appropriations Act, 2020, with $53.18 billion in adjusted net discretionary budget authority, $1.50 billion above the requested level. The Senate Appropriations Committee marked up S. 2582 with $53.18 billion in adjusted net discretionary budget authority, $1.50 billion above the requested level. The increase in funding was mainly due to additional funding for border barrier construction and more discretionary funding for agencies like the Coast Guard, Transportation Security Administration, and FEMA. The bill also included $17.35 billion for disaster relief and $190 million in OCO-designated funding. Congress passed a continuing resolution (CR) (P.L. 116-59) on September 27, 2019, temporarily extending funding at the FY2019 rate for operations through November 21, subsequently extended through December 20. The CR included provisions addressing needs of DHS under a CR, such as special apportionment of funds for Secret Service expenses related to the FY2020 presidential campaign. Section 133 accelerates apportionment for the Disaster Relief Fund, Section 134 extends National Flood Insurance Program authorization, and Section 135 reallocates funds for DHS management. Immigration provisions are extended by reference. For more details on FY2020 continuing resolutions, refer to CRS Report R45982. On December 16, 2019, the House Rules Committee released the text and explanatory statements for two consolidated appropriations bills. One bill, using H.R. 1158 as a legislative shell, included the FY2020 DHS annual appropriations measure with $50.47 billion in adjusted net discretionary budget authority. This amount was $1.22 billion below the Administration's request and $1.06 billion above the FY2019 enacted level. The bill also allocated $17.35 billion for FEMA in disaster relief funding and $190 million in additional funds. The homeland security appropriations bill, signed into law as P.L. 116-93, allocated $190 million in Overseas Contingency Operations designated funding to the Coast Guard. The bill passed the House by a vote of 280-138 and the Senate by a vote of 81-11. Discretionary appropriations provide the majority of funding for DHS operations. The DHS budget consists of a mix of funding sources, including disaster relief spending and OCO funding. Appropriations for DHS are typically organized into five titles, with the first four grouping components thematically and the fifth providing general direction. When DHS was established in 2003, components from other agencies were brought together over a few months within ongoing budget cycles. Congress and the Administration continued to provide funding without developing a new appropriations structure for the entire department. In 2014, DHS began working on a new Common Appropriations Structure (CAS) to standardize appropriations format across components. Operating with over 70 different appropriations and 100 Programs, Projects, and Activities hindered transparency and decision-making. After negotiations with Congress, DHS made its first budget request in the CAS. DHS implemented its first budget request in the Common Appropriations Structure for FY2017, converting legacy appropriations to a four-category structure covering Operations and Support, Procurement, Construction, and Improvements, Research and Development, and Federal Assistance for grant funding. The DHS implemented a budget request in FY2017 with a four-category structure covering Operations and Support, Procurement, Construction, and Improvements, Research and Development, and Federal Assistance for grant funding. Funding for law enforcement operational components, including U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) and Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), is provided in Title II of the annual DHS appropriations act. CBP secures borders and ports, while ICE focuses on preventing terrorism and illegal movement of people and goods. The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) provides security for the U.S. transportation system, the U.S. Coast Guard (USCG) is responsible for maritime safety and security, and the U.S. Secret Service (USSS) protects high-profile individuals and their residences. The USSS is responsible for protecting high-profile individuals, their families, residences, and visiting national and world leaders. They also investigate counterfeiting and financial crimes. The federal government spending process involves budget authority enactment by Congress, fund obligation by agencies, and payments for activities. Budget authority is established through appropriations acts or direct spending legislation and determines the amounts available for federal agencies to spend. The Antideficiency Act prohibits agencies from obligating more funds than enacted by Congress. Budget authority may be indefinite in amount and available on a one-year, multiyear, or no-year basis. Budget authority can be one-year, multiyear, or no-year. One-year authority is for a specific fiscal year, multiyear specifies a time range for spending, and no-year authority is indefinite. Obligations are incurred when agencies spend on personnel, contracts, services, creating a legal payment requirement. Outlays are the actual funds spent during the fiscal year. Budget authority allows federal agencies to incur obligations and authorize payments from the Treasury. Outlays represent the funds actually spent during the fiscal year, which may not always match the budget authority enacted. Discretionary funded agencies and programs, as well as appropriated entitlement programs, are funded annually through appropriations acts. Gross budget authority encompasses both discretionary and mandatory spending. Gross budget authority includes discretionary and mandatory spending. Discretionary spending is annually appropriated by Congress, while mandatory spending is provided in laws outside of appropriations acts. Within DHS, Coast Guard retirement pay is an example of appropriated mandatory spending. Offsetting Collections are funds collected by the federal government as part of business-type transactions, not considered federal revenue but counted as negative outlays. DHS net discretionary budget authority is composed of discretionary spending minus any fees or funds collected. The DHS budget includes mandatory entitlement programs like the Secret Service and Coast Guard retired pay accounts. Some entitlements are funded by permanent appropriations. The DHS budget includes mandatory entitlement programs like Secret Service and Coast Guard retirement pay accounts, funded by permanent or annual appropriations. Additionally, the budget contains offsetting Trust and Public Enterprise Funds, not appropriated by Congress, used to calculate gross budget authority. The congressional budget process determines annual appropriations, including for DHS, through a two-stage process. Congress sets spending totals in the annual budget resolution, which are then allocated among committees as 302(a) allocations for enactment in annual appropriations bills. Appropriations committees further allocate these discretionary funds among subcommittees for bill development. The appropriations committees allocate 302(a) discretionary funds among subcommittees for appropriations bills, known as 302(b) allocations. These allocations must not exceed the 302(a) allocation to enforce budget discipline. Adjustments can be made during the year by the appropriations committee. The Budget Control Act established discretionary spending caps for defense and nondefense spending from FY2012 through FY2021. Subsequent legislation amended these caps, including adjustments for overseas contingency operations, emergency spending, and disaster relief. Most of the DHS budget is considered nondefense spending. DHS's appropriations process has been influenced by three justifications outlined in the Act, including relief and appropriations for continuing disability reviews and control of health care fraud and abuse. The allowable adjustment for disaster relief was determined by the Office of Management and Budget using a specific formula until FY2019. The Bipartisan Budget Act of 2018 amended the formula for cap adjustment for the fiscal year, increasing the allowable size by adding 5% of emergency-designated funding for major disasters under the Stafford Act. Unused adjustment capacity now carries over indefinitely, rather than for just one year. OMB released a sequestration preview report for FY2020 in August 2019. The OMB released a sequestration preview report for FY2020, estimating an allowable adjustment of $17.5 billion, the second-largest for disaster relief. The estimate includes the 10-year average, 5% of Stafford Act spending since 2012, and carryover from the previous year. The final adjustment for FY2020 may vary from this estimate.
